awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Knowledge and Data-driven Design of Mechanical Metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditionally, materials have been designed through choices of molecular level composition and structure. With the advent of increasingly sophisticated material-forming techniques like additive manufacturing, structures repeated at microscale are also now being used to realize effective overall properties; these materials are termed "metamaterials". The most obvious gain for metamaterials versus traditional fully dense materials is in weight and material consumption, but there are also responses that are simply not achievable with fully dense polymers. In particular, 3D printing of polymers has reached a critical threshold of quality, speed, and size at which it can be used for production rather than just prototyping. The geometry within the repeated structural cell of a metamaterial critically influences the overall properties. Determining the optimal geometry requires a design framework distinct from that used for dense materials. This work will explore innovative ways of combining expert knowledge (i.e., physical laws, models, heuristics) and databases of actual and simulated material behaviors, using advanced machine learning and search algorithms to foster the discovery of metamaterials with desired properties. Progress in the project will promote the new field of data-driven design as well as advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare by facilitating the design of advanced materials with hitherto unknown, yet desirable combination of properties. Beyond this technological impact, this grant will serve to prepare the next generation of students for a new era of design for intelligent materials and structures. Doctoral, undergraduate, high school, and middle school students will be reached through in-lab research experiences and design outreach activities.

The central objective of this work is to create a design method for 3D printable elastomeric metamaterials that leverages both available engineering knowledge and data. The design space of interest will include two distinct geometry classes -- lattice materials and minimum energy surfaces. The methodology in this project will leverage physics-based models, existing knowledge, and data to minimize the resources needed to reach an acceptable design. The intermediate research objectives are to: (1) formulate and validate a comprehensive set of low computational cost mechanics models for lattice and minimum surface energy style metamaterials, together with a set of heuristics for designing such materials; (2) develop data-driven surrogate models and identify sources of and quantify uncertainty in predicted mechanical properties of 3D printed mechanical metamaterials; (3) develop knowledge representations and data fusion strategies to incorporate expert knowledge including physical laws, heuristics, and beliefs into the design of 3D printed metamaterials. In contrast to the current state-of-the-art for metamaterial design, the design framework that is produced by this grant will be well oriented to accommodate large deformation. This will facilitate design of printed metamaterials for properties such as toughness and failure strain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have developed new approaches to incorporate expert knowledge into the design of mechanical meta-materials and other complex systems such as satellite constellations. Specifically, we have developed a framework to incorporate expert design heuristics explicitly into multi-objective design optimization algorithms. A design heuristic is a context-dependent directive, based on intuition, tacit knowledge, or experiential understanding, that provides design process direction to increase the chance of reaching a satisfactory but not necessarily optimal solution. For example, when designing a 2D truss structure to have equal vertical and horizontal stiffness while minimizing weight, adding diagonal elements can help add stiffness while adding stability and not adding too much weight. Heuristics have been largely considered as qualitative guidelines to support a design process; in this project, we studied how to incorporate them explicitly into a formal design optimization framework. 

We considered three different implementations for heuristics: soft constraints, repair operators, and biased sampling functions. Soft constraints are penalty terms that are added to the objective functions of an optimization problem to favor satisfaction of a heuristic. For example, given a heuristic that in order to achieve similar vertical and horizontal stiffness we can try keeping the average inclination of the truss members around 45 degrees, the corresponding soft constraint implementation would penalize designs according to the deviation from that target value of 45 deg. Repair operators work by turning a design into a different design that is more consistent with the underlying heuristic (e.g., add/remove a vertical/horizontal member to increase/decrease stiffness in one direction). Biased sampling functions are functions that we use to sample from a design space in a way that is biased towards satisfying the heuristic. For example, rather than randomly deciding whether to include each possible truss member with a standard "coin flip" (50% probability of including it), we can bias that probability so that diagonal members are more likely.

We discovered early on that while many heuristics improve search performance, not all of them do. Even heuristics that are "good" and relevant for a given problem may actually degrade search performance. Therefore, we developed a method to identify which heuristics are actually beneficial for a given problem at hand. For soft constraints, the method works by synthesizing a number of designs and calculating an index that is essentially a weighted average of correlation coefficients between the heuristic satisfaction function and the functions defining goodness in the problem formulation (i.e., constraints and objectives). For repair operators, the method works by generating a number of designs randomly, then applying the operator to each design to produce a second set of designs, and calculating an index that is the difference of hypervolumes of the first vs the second set, where the hypervolume is a measure of performance in multi-objective optimization (simply the region of the design space that is dominated by a set of designs, i..e that contains designs that are worse in all metrics than at least one design in the set). For biased sampling functions, it works the same as for repair operators except the second set is generated with the biased sampling function. The calculation of these indices allows a user to identify which heuristics are actually "promising" for a given design problem.

The next step in the framework was to actually incorporate these promising heuristics into the design optimization process. For soft constraints, we considered two approaches: one with fixed weights for the soft constraints, and one with adaptive weights that are learned over time. For the repair operators, we used adaptive operator selection, a method that keeps track of which operators are generating good designs and uses those operators more often. For the biased sampling functions, we used them to generate the initial population of designs to start the optimization.

We performed a large study where we compared all of these methods (soft constraints, repair operators, biased sampling functions, and no heuristics) on 4 different problems: two meta-material design problems and two satellite constellation design problems. The results showed that including heuristics leads to better performance in most cases. In addition, the results showed that implementing heuristics as repair operators using adaptive operator selection is a more robust approach than implementing them as soft constraints, either with fixed or adaptive weights. The biased sampling function approach was extremely useful in some cases, but not useful at all in other cases. 

In addition to the results of the experiments, we developed a set of guidelines for practitioners to help them understand when and how to use design heuristics and optimization. Ultimately, this project is a step in the direction of enabling a human-machine symbiotic design process for complex systems.
